justification: The article notes that "The most popular measure of punishment sensitivity in humans … has been self-reporting via the Behavioral Inhibition/Behavioral Activation Scales (Carver & White, 1994)."
It states that the Iowa Gambling Task "potently identifies maladaptive decision-making tendencies" by contrasting decks that differ in reward and punishment contingencies.

The authors describe using "a task in rats that isolates and dissociates different forms of learning" where one lever is punished (R1→CS1+) and the other is not (R2→CS-) to measure punishment learning.

measured_by: Planets and Pirates task (digital conditioned-punishment game)
justification: They explain that they "developed a digital 'Planets and Pirates' variant of the rodent conditioned punishment task for use in humans" which allows identification of punishment-sensitive versus punishment-insensitive participants.
